1.rationale:
Let’s analyze our situation step‐by‐step.

Current board and positions:
• Our snake (ID 1) is now at (3,2).
• The enemy snake (ID 0) is at (6,5).
• Apples are at (4,9), (6,6), (8,9), (9,6), and (7,0).

Distances from our head (3,2) using Manhattan distance:
• (7,0): |7–3| + |0–2| = 4 + 2 = 6
• (6,6): |6–3| + |6–2| = 3 + 4 = 7
• (4,9): 1 + 7 = 8
• (9,6): 6 + 4 = 10
• (8,9): 5 + 7 = 12

The (7,0) apple is the closest. Our earlier strategy was to head for (7,0), and now that our snake is at (3,2) (coming from the RIGHT move that took us there), we need to keep progressing toward that same target.

A plausible and safe route from (3,2) to (7,0) would be:
1. Move RIGHT to (4,2)
2. Continue RIGHT along the bottom region (or a mix of RIGHT then DOWN as needed) until our x coordinate is near 7, and then head downward.
We must also mind that while enemy snake #0 is near (6,5) and likely eyeing the (6,6) apple (which is just one move away upward), they aren’t in our immediate path. By remaining in an open area and proceeding RIGHT, we keep our trajectory toward (7,0) while maintaining flexibility.

Between our immediate options from (3,2):
– UP would take us further away from our target (and closer to the upper-bound apples).
– DOWN might seem attractive because it slightly reduces our distance (from 6 to 5), but it brings us closer to the board’s lower edge, potentially limiting our maneuverability.
– RIGHT clearly opens our path, keeping us in a spacious central corridor while steadily progressing toward (7,0).

Given these considerations, it makes sense to continue with our original plan and move RIGHT. 

Next-turn reminder for myself:
• If the path remains clear, I’ll keep moving RIGHT.
• I’ll gradually steer my snake downward once our x coordinate gets closer to 7.
• I must keep an eye on enemy snake movements (especially if they try to jump from (6,5) toward (6,6) or even pivot toward the (7,0) apple).

Decided next move: RIGHT.
